question: How much protein should I be aiming for in a day?
answer:
There is no exact amount of protein overall to be having in a day. There’s a recommended daily intake of protein (RDA/RDI) which is the amount of protein that you need to get to avoid protein malnutrition. That’s about 0.8-1 gram of protein per kg of body weight per day. You probably don’t need us to tell you that avoiding protein malnutrition is NOT the same thing as an optimal amount of protein per day. For example, people that want to build muscle mass will be aiming for at least 1 gram of protein per pound of body weight per day, which is about 2g per kg of body weight.

So, for that person, say they’re 80kg, would instead want to be having around 160g of protein a day - which is a huge amount. So this is where we generally say for most people it's around somewhere in between the RDA/RDI and that recommended amount in order to gain muscle mass, so generally around 1.2-1.4g per kg of body weight per day. "

question: Can I have collagen every day?
answer: The current research shows that it's safe for collagen to make up about 35-40% of your total protein requirements. This is because collagen is not what we call a complete protein, it's missing one of your key amino acids: tryptophan. Tryptophan is important for your brain’s neurotransmitters to work properly. So for you, that might be having collagen in your breakfast as a protein source, but not necessarily having it for lunch and dinner as well.

question: Why is my protein powder making my stomach hurt?
answer:
It’s not common however, a few factors could cause this:

- Some people don't tolerate stevia or monk fruit or other sweeteners that many brands use
- Soy or whey in protein powder (particularly if it’s the main ingredient) can often exacerbate IBS symptoms for people who suffer with this
- Some lower quality protein powders often contain fillers like xanthan gum, carrageenan and cellulose which can cause digestive / GI upsets

If this is happening, it might be worthwhile getting different samples of protein powder (including an unsweetened one) to try different ones and see how you personally react.
"

question: Can I have protein powder every day?
answer: As far as we can see from current research, it’s okay to have protein powder every day. However, we do encourage you to, if you can, focus on getting your protein mostly from whole foods. Then use protein powder as your ‘top up’ rather than your main protein source.  Some people find that whole foods or ‘real foods’ can help with better feelings of satiety in comparison to a powdered drink format. A smoothie with a mixture of both can be a good happy medium.

question: Is almond meal the same as almond flour?
answer: It's a little different. Almond meal is where they grind the whole almond with the skins on thus would be a bit more course and almond flour are usually blanched almonds with out the skins, and the grind can be much finer.

question: Is it okay to eat eggs?
answer: Unless you have an allergy or an intolerance to eggs there shouldn't be any issues - we've not seen any conclusive medical evidence that would suggest they would be impacting symptoms greatly."

question: I'm allergic to eggs, what can I use in the recipes instead?
answer:
Flaxseed eggs can make a great whole food egg alternative, especially for recipes like pancakes, brownies, muffins or seedy breads (it doesn’t work in every recipe unfortunately).
To make a flaxseed egg (equivalent to 1 egg), combine 1 Tbsp flaxseed meal (ground flaxseeds) with 2½ Tbsp water and allow to sit for about 5 minutes to form a gel-like texture.

question: Can I have sugar alcohols?
answer:
They aren't our go-to suggestion for sweeteners, if possible - try to use monkfruit or stevia instead. We don't have enough definitive research to give them the ‘all clear’ and they can cause stomach upsets and issues in some people - particularly if you already have gut issues such as IBS or SIBO.

In some cases however, such as baking, monkfruit or stevia might not be as good of a substitution as sugar alcohols like xylitol, erythritol and allulose as their consistency is closer to traditional sugar. Just because this baking uses sugar alcohols, it likely should still be treated as a sometimes food. "

question: Is tofu a good source of protein?
answer: Yes, tofu is a good option. Try to find one that says it's made from soybeans rather than ‘soy protein isolate’ or ‘SPI’. SPI is the by-product of soybean oil processing so has undergone a lot of food processing before then undergoing more processing to become tofu.

question: Is peanut butter is "worse" than other nut butters?
answer:
All nut butters are healthy options for your serving of fat for your meals or snacks. Try to buy one that is 100% nuts (and/or seeds) and nothing else i.e. no added oil or sugar.

Peanuts have slightly more carbs than other nuts (because peanuts are technically a legume rather than a tree nut!), so you might find that using an almond or cashew butter can have a better effect on your blood sugar levels - especially if you are eating a nut butter at breakfast.

Otherwise just opt for the nut butter you prefer.

Top tip, You can make your own by roasting nuts (or buying pre roasted) and blitzing in a food processor until they become a paste. This can be a cost effective option.

question: Is peanut butter is "worse" than other nut butters?
answer:
All nut butters are healthy options for your serving of fat for your meals or snacks - simply opt for the one that you prefer! Try to buy one that is 100% nuts (and/or seeds) and nothing else i.e. no added oil or sugar.

Top tip, You can make your own by roasting nuts (or buying pre roasted) and blitzing in a food processor until they become a paste. This can be a cost effective option. "

question: My protein powder tastes gross, how can I fix this?
answer:
There are a few things you can try:

Unsweetened coconut milk - it's a bit higher fat so it tends to taste less bland and watery than some other nut milks, instead more creamy and sweet (even in its unsweetened form).
Note: You might want to use ‘drinking’ coconut milk rather than canned coconut milk as the calories can differ significantly.
A squeeze of lemon - If your protein tastes bitter, try adding a squeeze of lemon juice. This offsets the bitterness and provides a nice, smooth, palatable flavour.
A dash of vanilla essence - just a dash is all you need to add a little flavour and mask some of the protein flavour.
A teaspoon of dark cocoa
A pinch of cinnamon

question: What do you think about seed cycling?
answer: Seeds are a brilliant and nutrient-rich food, but there is no substantive evidence for seed cycling (at the moment).

question: What if I don't like protein powder?
answer: If you don't like protein powder, you don't need to buy it. If you're looking to get more protein in your diet alongside whole food sources, you could try using a collagen powder as they tend to dissolve better than protein powders do.

question: What if I don't like protein powder?
answer: If you don't like protein powder, you don't need to buy it. If you're looking to get more protein in your diet alongside whole food sources, you could try using a collagen powder as they tend to dissolve better than protein powders do.

question: Can I have collagen if I'm vegan / vegetarian / plant based?
answer: If you're vegan, vegetarian or plant based, collagen powder won't be an option for you. Collagen is found in the bones, ligaments and connective tissue of animals. This means the two supplement sources of collagen are bovine or marine - neither of which will be suitable for you if you're following a vegan, vegetarian or plant based lifestyle.

question: How many minutes of strength training should we be aiming for each session?
answer: It depends on what you can achieve in the day! 30 minutes to 1 hour for strength training is a good ballpark, but if you can only squeeze in 20 minutes, then do 20!

question: How many minutes of strength training should we be aiming for each session?
answer: It depends on your threshold for exercise and what you can realistically achieve in your day. If your adrenals aren't absolutely slammed from overdoing it then 30 minutes to 1 hour for strength training is a good ballpark.

question: How many minutes of strength training should we be aiming for each session?
answer: It depends on your threshold for exercise and what you can realistically achieve in your day. If your adrenals aren't absolutely slammed from overdoing it then 30-45 minutes for strength training is a good ballpark. If you begin to feel tired or anxious during the workout, use this as your cue to stop early. If you need to rush other areas of your day to fit this training in, you'll effectively be adding to your stress load by doing this exercise, so it might be worth giving it a miss entirely on this day, or just doing 15 minutes.

question: How many minutes of HIIT should we be aiming for each session?
answer: It depends on your threshold for exercise of such high intensity and what you can realistically achieve in a day. 20-30 minutes for HIIT is a good ballpark, however we don't suggest doing anymore than 2 HIIT sessions per week. If you find HIIT training starts to impact your sleep quality or your stress levels we recommend peeling back a little.

question: How many minutes of HIIT should we be aiming for each session?
answer:
It depends on your threshold for exercise of such high intensity and what you can realistically achieve in a day. If you feel your stress levels are under control, 20-30 minutes for HIIT is a good ballpark, however we don't suggest doing anymore than 1 HIIT session per week.
If you find HIIT training starts to impact your sleep quality or your stress levels we recommend peeling back a little. Even 10 minutes of HIIT workouts, with 4 minutes of the maximum effort activity time can be enough to trigger some sweaty endorphins but you won’t suffer the negative effects of cortisol.

But remember to check in with yourself, and don’t overdo it!

question: I have [insert condition here] and are there any products or supplements here that could contraindicate?
answer: Medication interactions and pharmacology is not our area of expertise, this question is one that you should speak to your doctor and/or a pharmacist about.

question: Should I stop taking supplements if I fall pregnant?
answer: The supplements you'll want to remove when you fall pregnant, if you haven't already, are any herbal supplements. The reason is that we don't have enough substantial evidence on their effects in pregnant women. When it comes to vitamins and minerals, these are fine but you may need to change your dosage as your demands change. Please consult your doctor, nutritionist or dietitian for information.

question: My bowel habits have changed since starting supplements. Should I stop using them?
answer: If you're finding that your bowel movements have changed when introducing supplements, we'd suggest removing all supplements and reintroducing them one-by-one, a week at a time. This way you can see if there is one specific supplement that has caused this. You can also try reducing the dosage and working your way back up. It may be the additional ingredients in the supplement that is causing you bowel upsets, rather than the active ingredient, so sometimes trying a different brand of supplement that has different tableting aids can help. If you're still having trouble after trying these steps, please consult with your doctor, nutritionist or dietitian.

question: When should I come off the Pill / hormonal birth control?
answer: Whether to stay on the pill or not is completely up to you. There are negatives and positives to all types of birth control. You are more than welcome to stay on birth control while implementing the changes here in the program. If you're wanting to come off hormonal birth control (HBC) to conceive, please be aware that this could take some time. Some people ovulate in their first cycle without HBC but for many women with PCOS this isn't the case. Please bear that in mind.

question: What if I can't afford to order all of the recommended supplements?
answer: No worries! These aren’t compulsory and we don’t want you re-mortgaging your house to afford them. The only exception is if you are deficient in a vitamin or mineral, as you do need these to be within range for you to function optimally. Nutrient deficiencies can contribute to your PCOS symptoms. If you can afford some, choose those that you are deficient in.

question: Is [insert vegetable here] starchy or non-starchy?
answer: If you’re wondering if a vegetable is a starchy or non-starchy, you can simply google “is [insert vegetable here] a non-starchy vegetable?”. Google is usually pretty accurate with it’s answer. Another way to tell is if it grows above the ground, then it’s usually a non-starchy vegetable. There are a few exceptions to this rule, but in general it works.

question: Is Provera the same as micronised progesterone?
answer: No. Provera is a progestin, the synthetic version of progesterone. If you are looking for micronised progesterone, common brand names include Prometrium and Uterogestan. These will be different depending on what country you live in.

question: What thermometer should I use for tracking my basal body temperature (BBT)?
answer: If you are or wanting to track your basal body temperature, use a basal thermometer than has 2 decimal places (ie. 36.42°C).

question: I’m getting a lot of pain with my PCOS - is this normal?
answer: Pain is not a symptom of PCOS. This can be quite an ambiguous symptom so it’s best to check in with your gynaecologist and investigate the possibility of endometriosis, adenomyosis or ovarian cysts. You can have these as well as PCOS.

question: What are some useful tools to have in my kitchen to make preparing more whole food based meals easier?
answer:
"There are so many kitchen tools and gadgets available, but we believe that there are only a few which are really essential, including:
A food processor: why waste time chopping when a food processor can do all of the hard work for you? If not, a good grater will do the trick.
A cast iron frypan: an incredibly versatile tool that will help you to save on time and extra washing up. Just make sure that you stay away from any chemical, non-stick pans.
Sharp knives: you’ll find that cooking is much quicker and enjoyable when you have good knives.
A variety of storage containers: these are great for transporting, refrigerating, or freezing food. Always make sure to buy glass or metal containers, as plastic is bad for those of us with PCOS.
Slow (or pressure pot) cooker: these are great for making meals in bulk and great for hearty winter cooking.

question: Will my symptoms get better after menopause?
answer: Not necessarily, sometimes your symptoms can get worse after menopause. This is why it's so important to work on and manage your root cause, to ensure you're well equipped to handle any symptoms as you go through perimenopasue and into menopause. Lara Briden's 'Hormone Repair Manual: Every Woman's Guide to Healthy Hormones After 40' is a great resource if you're about to go through or are going through perimenopause.

question: What's the difference between polycystic ovaries and ovarian cysts?
answer:
Ovarian cysts are (contrary to popular belief) not caused by PCOS. Ovarian cysts (pathological cysts) are large fluid filled sacs that can burst and cause immense pain. They can also grow very large and block the blood supply in the ovaries. Pathological cysts are cysts caused by abnormal cell growth and are not related to the menstrual cycle or the PCOS ‘functional cysts’. Pathological cysts develop from either the cells used to create eggs or the cells that cover the outer part of the ovary. Pathological cysts are usually non-cancerous.

The ‘cysts’ (functional cysts) that are found on the ovaries in PCOS aren’t really cysts at all. These are ‘follicles’ or baby eggs that just haven’t ‘hatched’ when you couldn’t ovulate, i.e. they have a function which was meant to release an egg.

You can have BOTH an ovarian cyst and PCOS - but just because you have PCOS doesn’t mean you’ll have an ovarian cyst and if you have ovarian cysts, that doesn't necessarily mean you have PCOS.

question: Why am I more hungry in the week or so before my period?
answer: In the week or so before your period, you're in the luteal phase of your cycle. At this time, your metabolic rate increases (in some cases you can burn up to 300 calories more a day) and you should have more progesterone than other times in your cycle. Both of these factors can influence your hunger! It can be helpful in this stage of your cycle to increase your fat and protein intake to help you feel more satiated and provide your body with the additional energy it needs.

question: Can you ovulate twice in one cycle?
answer: Yes. It's possible to ovulate twice in a cycle, but this will happen within 12-24 hours of the ovulation occurring. So, for example, you can't ovulate on day 10 and then ovulate again on day 20. If you're seeing increases in the wet cervical mucus on, say, day 10 and again on day 20, what this will mean is that your body has been trying to ovulate on day 10 and it hasn't quite reached ovulation. This is why we use both the BBT and CF, because then you can use the temperature to confirm whether you did ovulate or not.

question: Can you tell if you've ovulated from a temperature dip and then an increase?
answer: Start by looking for three temperatures that are at least 0.3°F (0.1°C) but more likely 0.5 to 1°F (0.2 to 0.6°C) higher than thesix temperatures that immediately precede it (a simple way to remember this is three over six). Three temperatures higher than six lower ones are your ovulation temperature spike. If you see this, congratulations—you ovulated!

question: Can't I just use temperature to tell me when I'm going to ovulate? Do I have to use cervical fluid as well?
answer: Oral temperature can only confirm that ovulation has occured. We can't use it to indicate when ovulation is going to happen. Your body releases an egg and increases your basal body temperature to incubate it, so it can't be used to predict the lead up to ovulation. You may have read online that getting a dip in BBT right before ovulation can signal the fertile window, however oral temperature measurements aren't sensitive enough to pick this up.

question: If you're getting your period, does that automatically mean you're ovulating?
answer: You can get a period without ovulating. While it's not common to get a period every month without ovulating, it is common for at least some of your cycles to be anovulatory.

question: How can I support my gut while doing low FODMAP?
answer:
Here are some important tips for optimal GI health during your time on a low FODMAP diet:
- Liver from pastured animals one to two times weekly will help to replenish your vitamin B12, iron, and other nutrients you may be deficient in due to dysbiosis.
- Homemade bone broths can be very healing for the GI tract.
- Meats are most easily digested when prepared at low cooking temperatures, using moist cooking techniques. Consider using a slow-cooker, stewing, braising or poaching for at least 30 days.
- Vegetables should be well-cooked with any seeds removed to improve digestibility; minimize your intake of raw, fibrous fruits and vegetables.
- Be very careful when eating out, and consider calling ahead to ask about preparation methods and ingredients to find an option that works for you.

Remember that low FODMAP isn't a permanent diet - you will need to reintroduce to identify what foods trigger you."

question: What is a tool kit?
answer:
A tool kit looks similar to a lesson, but rather than explaining the reason for something as a lesson would, a tool kit will have handy and helpful tips and tricks, or knowledge you may want to refer back to. For this reason, you can’t ‘favorite’ a tool kit, instead it’ll automatically store in your ‘tool kit’ under your favorites tab so it’s always there for you to refer back to.
"You’ll have an expert on hand to help you through the program. You can reach out to your expert in the chat functionality with any burning questions about the program, or for motivation and support.

question: Where can I find support?
answer:
To discuss a larger matter, such as diving deeping into additional health concerns, or interpreting test results, you can book a consultation with an expert via a video or audio call.

Our people say that our Ovie community is the best support crew. In the community forum/ FACEBOOK GROUP you can share ideas, common struggles, solutions and successes with others going through the program too. It’s a safe and empowering space to communicate with and support each other. Feel free to jump on and introduce yourself, we’d love to learn more about you and your story so far! LINK BUTTON TO COMMUNITY?"

question: What if I just really love the high intensity exercise and want to do it 6 x a week?
answer: We hear you, We've been where you are! But we also know what it's like when your stress hormones say 'NO MORE'. It's not fun (constantly exhausted, brain fog, weight gain, irritable, moody, and the rest!), and it can take YEARS to recover from. So while it's your decision how you exercise, we can only tell you that it’s not the most effective thing to do 6x a week, and could have consequences in the long run for your overall health, fitness and mobility.

question: How much caffeine is in different beverages?
answer:
Coffee is typically our main source of caffeine, but it’s not the only drink that contains caffeine!

Coffee (Starbucks venti): 475mg (this has 4 shots of espresso coffee)
Coffee (double espresso): 180-250mg
Energy drink (240mL): 75mg
Black tea: 46mg
Green tea: 40mg
Instant coffee (1 tsp): between 30-90mg (brand dependent)
Dark chocolate: (1.5 ounce) 20mg
Decaf coffee: 9mg

Top Tip: Decaf coffee has been processed to remove the caffeine, but new technology means this can be done with water alone (rather than chemicals). Opt for a water processed decaf coffee where possible. "

question: Does caffeine affect my fertility?
answer: Although the research is only emerging, studies suggest that high amounts of caffeine (2-3 cups of coffee or 200-300mg) may affect fertility. This isn’t conclusive yet, but if you are trying to conceive, it might be wise to limit your consumption of coffee to a single shot espresso daily, or better yet, choose decaf most of the time.

question: Does caffeine affect medication, and vice versa?
answer: A number of medications can be affected by caffeine, so be sure to check in with your specific medication. One to note is if you’re taking hormonal birth control (HBC), you’re less able to metabolize caffeine. One study found that oral contraceptives almost doubled the time it takes to metabolize caffeine (10 hours vs. six hours). So if you’re genetically a slow metabolizer of caffeine and you’re on HBC, you’ve got a double whammy and have caffeine floating around in your body for much longer.

question: Do I need to get any testing done prior to starting supplementing?
answer: Potentially. This would be to understand your nutrient levels and whether any deficiencies might be at play. Blood results that show low or deficient amounts of certain nutrients will require different dosages of supplementation to restore your levels to the optimum range. If your levels are too high you will not supplement. We will talk more about this in an upcoming lesson.

question: Where can I find more information on inositol?
answer:
"When it comes to improving insulin, first up is Inositol. Inositol is a naturally occurring compound in the body and it’s actually a really important messenger in our insulin pathway. As our insulin rises, we need more inositol to do its job and if we supplement, we might actually be able to improve our insulin sensitivity. There are two types of inositol, myo and d-chiro. Myo inositol alone has been found to be helpful for improving insulin. But the combination of myo and d-chiro is more effective not only for insulin, but also for supporting ovulation and overall ovarian health.

Studies have shown that inositol is the most effective supplement for insulin resistance in PCOS, and a 2019 analysis of the research found it to be as effective as metformin for improving insulin. However this doesn’t mean you have to choose - you can take both!

question: Where can I find more information about a B vitamin and chromium supplement?
answer:
B vitamins are very important for allowing your insulin to work properly. They’re also essential in a number of other processes including hormone production. Chromium is another mineral that’s essential in insulin sensitivity, and it’s really hard to get in your diet.

A 2017 review of all the research found that chromium had a positive effect in improving insulin, BMI and testosterone in people with PCOS.

This blend is particularly beneficial for anyone taking Metformin, which strips the body of a number of essential nutrients, namely vitamin B12.

Note: if you're taking a prenatal, you don't need this as well. Not to be taken whilst pregnant as it contains herbs. "

question: Where can I find more information about a stress manager?
answer:
Adaptogenic herbs to help your body to cope better with stress. They can’t reduce the stress you’re under, but they can help buffer the damaging effects on your body. The Stress Manager is a blend of herbs that have shown to have an adaptogenic effect on our body’s stress response.

A clinical trial has shown that rhodiola (one of the herbs in this blend) significantly reduced self-reported anxiety, stress, anger, confusion and depression and achieved significant improvements in mood after just 14 days. Rhodiola also has been shown to reduce fatigue while improving mood and cognition in those feeling stressed or anxious and rhodiola and schisandra markedly decreased the stress-induced elevation of stress hormones.

question: Where can I find more information about magnesium?
answer: Magnesium is another essential mineral in the body. It has an important role in both our insulin sensitivity AND stress response. It’s now thought that magnesium deficiency could be one of the predisposing factors to developing insulin resistance due to its role in glucose metabolism, and supplementation with magnesium has shown to increase insulin sensitivity in clinical trials. Research also shows us that magnesium deficiency can lead to anxiety and also a disruption to the stress response. And considering that 50% or more of the population of the US don’t get enough magnesium from their food, this is a good reason to supplement with magnesium if you think your PCOS is driven by adrenal activity and insulin activity, especially if you also suffer from anxiety.

question: What if my test shows I’m deficient in a vitamin or mineral?
answer: If you’re deficient in a vitamin or mineral, we suggest booking a consultation with your health coach to determine a supplementation plan to help you get back into the functional (optimal) nutrient range.

question: What if my test shows I have high levels of a vitamin or mineral (excluding iron)?
answer: If you have levels outside the reference range and you’re not supplementing, then this might be a sign of something else. For example, it’s very hard to get above the reference range of vitamin B12 just through diet. Instead, high levels might be an indicator of a genetic predisposition that means your body struggles to store vitamin B12 in your cells, so instead it’s accumulating in your blood. If this is you, it's important to work with a functional medicine doctor who can do some functional and possibly genetic testing to help you establish why your nutrients levels are high to help you manage this.

question: Where can I find more information about magnesium?
answer: Magnesium is another essential mineral in the body, and it has an important role in our glucose metabolism and insulin action. It’s now thought that magnesium deficiency could be one of the predisposing factors to developing insulin resistance, and supplementation with magnesium has shown to increase insulin sensitivity in clinical trials. And considering that 50% or more of the population of the US don’t get enough magnesium from their food, this is a good reason to supplement with magnesium when we’re wanting to increase our insulin sensitivity.

question: What if a supplement reacts with me?
answer:
If you experience any symptoms after starting to take any supplements, please STOP taking them and follow these guidelines:
Step 1: Stop taking all supplements and wait until the symptoms disappear (if they don't, it's likely it wasn't the supplement that caused the issue).
Step 2: Once the symptoms have resolved add the supplements back in one by one, with at least 7-10 days between each new supplement. Start with the one you suspect might be causing it. If the symptom doesn't re-appear, add in the next one.
Step 3: Keep going until you've added them all back in.

If you have a reaction to a supplement stop taking this immediately, and speak to your GP or health professional to try establish why this might be.

question: What if my supplements are out of stock?
answer: The supplements we recommend are quite well-known and big companies so if you google the name and brand you’ll likely find an alternate supplier. Alternatively, you can contact the distributor to alert you when they are back in stock. So long as the delay isn’t long this is fine to wait. If there is a long delay and you can’t source elsewhere, we suggest looking at the second supplement option that we’ve recommended for the interim.

question: What if I can't get the recommended supplements in my country?
answer:
In some areas of the world, it's very hard to buy supplements online because of the customs and laws with importing these. If this is the case we recommend you look locally for your supplements, and here are some tips to help you with this:

Look on the label of the recommended supplements to see what some of those active ingredients are. For example, a vitamin D supplement’s active ingredient is Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol). If the supplement is a blend and you can't get a similar combination product, try getting some individual supplements that have those active ingredients.
If you’re already working with a naturopath or naturopathic doctor they may be able to get you similar practitioner-only supplements. Discuss the possibility of them sourcing these supplements for you at your next consultation.
If you aren’t working with any health professional, see if you can find a herbal dispensary or health food store nearby. They often have a naturopath on site that can help you get the supplements you need.

question: Where can I find more information on the Stress Manager adaptogenic herbs?
answer:
Adaptogenic herbs to help your body to cope better with stress. They can’t reduce the stress you’re under, but they can help buffer the damaging effects on your body. The Stress Manager is a blend of herbs that have shown to have an adaptogenic effect on our body’s stress response.

A clinical trial has shown that rhodiola (one of the herbs in this blend) significantly reduced self-reported anxiety, stress, anger, confusion and depression and achieved significant improvements in mood after just 14 days. Rhodiola also has been shown to reduce fatigue while improving mood and cognition in those feeling stressed or anxious and rhodiola and schisandra markedly decreased the stress-induced elevation of stress hormones.

question: Where can I find more information on magnesium glycinate?
answer: Magnesium is another essential mineral in the body, and can play a role in our stress response. Research shows us that magnesium deficiency can lead to anxiety and also a disruption to the stress response. Further research suggests stress depletes the body of magnesium. And considering that 50% or more of the population of the US don’t get enough magnesium from their food, this is a good reason to supplement with magnesium if you think your PCOS is driven by adrenal activity, especially if you also suffer from anxiety.

question: Where can I find more information on B vitamins?
answer:
Vitamin B5 (pantethine) plays a part in producing the sex and stress-related hormones that are produced in the adrenal glands, as well as supporting the normal functioning of our adrenal glands. Both of which play a role in reducing the damaging effects of stress.

B vitamins, especially vitamin B12 and Folate B9, are very important for a vast number of  processes including hormone production, nerve conduction and converting our food into energy. The optimal level for B12 is under debate, however It is well-established in the scientific literature that  people with B12 levels that are considered “normal”  in the U.S. present with clear symptoms of B12 deficienc

question: Where can I find more information about N-acetyl Cysteine (NAC)?
answer: NAC is a readily absorbed antioxidant and a precursor for glutathione, a very strong antioxidant (that isn’t easily absorbed by humans) which is able to protect important components of our cells from damage by oxidants or free radicals. As high stress levels can generate increased levels of oxidative stress, supplementing to support our antioxidant levels can be beneficial. Supplementing with NAC has also shown to support ovulatory responses and hormone imbalances.

question: Why do my testosterone levels look fine in my blood results but I have really bad hirsutism?
answer:
This is very common, and that’s because your testosterone has been
converted into its more potent form DHT (dihydrotestosterone). It’s
DHT that’s getting into our tissue and causing our PCOS hirsutism.
As testosterone levels aren’t taking into account DHT levels, and
can’t pick up the DHT localised in the tissues, your blood results
for testosterone can look in range.

question: Do I need to check in with my doctor before I start supplementing?
answer: YES! You please check with your doctor first before taking any new supplements, especially if you are on any medication, as some supplements (particularly herbs) can interfere with certain medications.

question: What about whey protein?
answer: Whey protein is fine to use if dairy isn’t an issue for you (reasons might be acne, insulin resistance, endometriosis, adenomyosis or any auto-immune conditions, as dairy can be stimulating/inflammatory). This is because whey protein is a byproduct of the dairy industry.
tags: dairy, acne, whey, endometriosis, protein, protein powder, adenomyosis, insulin resistance

question: It’s important to form a support system
answer:
Be prepared to lean on your support system throughout the process - those that cheer you on and keep you accountable. We find that sharing your journey with friends and family who are supportive can be so helpful. However, if you have any acquaintances or people that have strong opinions, it may not be worth getting into a discussion about the changes you’re making at all. If you find yourself in an uncomfortable dialogue, you could either responds with some of the following:
  • “I don’t feel like it”
  • “Maybe later”
  • “No thanks, I’m okay”
  • “Thanks for offering but I’m fine”
  • “I’m alright”
  • “Thanks for thinking of me”
  • Simply steer the conversation back on to them
Or you can make it clear for them that your body is not up for discussion. This gives a pretty clear message - my choices are not up to you. Remember this is about your health, not theirs.

question: I’ve heard including d chiro is important when it comes to inositol?
answer: You’re correct, d chiro inositol is important. There are two types of inositol, myo and d-chiro. Myo inositol alone has been found to be helpful for improving insulin. But the combination of myo and d-chiro is more effective not only for insulin, but also for supporting ovulation and overall ovarian health. The d chiro part, although a tiny proportion (in a 1:40 ratio with myo inositol) is typically much more expensive, so if ovulation isn’t your goal investing in just myo inositol alone for insulin function might be a more cost effective solution for you.
